bibl.title: Report on David Manrique by Henry R. Muller, [1923]

div1.p: Muller describes the liver of a suspected yellow fever case.

div1.head: Report on David Manrique by Henry R. Muller, [1923]
div1.p:
Liver. In the hematoxylin and eosin sections, the general
architecture appears well preserved. The lobules and liver cords are dis-
tinct. There is a rather marked “round cell” infiltration of the portal
connective tissue, and in places this connective tissue is slightly more
abundant than normal. The bile ducts are normal. The liver cells, except
in the areas of necrosis to be described later, show distinct clearly stain-
ing nuclei, but some of these nuclei are very large. Mitotic figures are
not present. The liver cells of the inner 1/3 to 1/2 of the lobules are
vacuolated, and in sections stained with Scarlet R. These vacuoles are
found to correspond with fat droplets. These fat droplets are of moderate
size, usually several in a cell. A few very large round globules of fat
are also present. The nuclei of the fat-containing cells are not pushed
off to one side. There are several miliary foci of necrosis, some situated
around the central vein, but others have no constant relation to the lobule.
All these foci of necrosis contain many large bacilli, easily seen with high-
dry objective. It is most probable, therefore, that these areas of necrosis
are post mortem changes. The endothelial cells of the sinuses are normal
and contain no pigment. Pigmentation of the liver cells is marked, and
this pigment is present in two forms, one as a fine yellowish brown granular
pigment within the liver cells, chiefly around the central vein, the other
ad clumps of dark brown needle-like crystals, resembling hematoidin crystals.
This latter is therefore very likely a recent formation. There is very
little blood in the sinuses.

Kidney. Microscopically, the kidney presents a considerably altered
Case #2.
-2-
appearance. Most of the epithelial cells of the convoluted tubules are
swollen and necrotic, and many of the nuclei are absent. These cells in the
Scarlet R sections show no fat, but the cells of the ascending and descending
loops, which are better preserved, show very fine fat granules in the cyto-
plasm. Some convoluted tubules are entirely denuded of epithelium, proba-
bly a post mortem change. Dark brown pigment granules are scattered over
the entire section. Large bacilli are also diffusely scattered throughout
the section. An old lesion in the form of many completely sclerosed and
hyalinized glomeruli is present.

list.item:
Liver:
1. Fatty degeneration of inner 1/3 to 1/2 of liver lobules.
2. A few minute areas of necrosis, together with large bacilli.
3. Marked “round-cell” infiltration of portal connective tissue.
4. Pigmentation of liver cells.

Kidney:
1. Cloudy swelling and necrosis of epithelium of convoluted tubules.
2. Fatty degeneration of epithelium of descending and ascending loops.
3. Complete denudation of epithelium of some convoluted tubules.
4. Presence of large bacilli.
5. Hyalinized glomeruli.
